chapter.title: Sensors
chapter.para: In Sensorsthe user can make queries, manage and make configurations of their network infrastructure through the creation and edition of domains and sensors. There are many views that offer the possibility to make different actions on their network elements.

Sensors is available in the top right margin of the header menu, next to Tools section and User's Area. This menu area is named as Configuration zone, because unlike the options available in the top left margin (Analysis), these allow the complete management and configuration of the Manager and sensors: rules policies, alarms, cluster configuration or user's management, among other actions.

section.title: Sensors: menu and options
section.para: The organization of this sections is very similar (in terms of structure) to the other parts of the web. We can find in this case:

listitem.para: Section submenu: configuration and sensors'management options.
Expand all: It fully expands the sensor tree.
Collapse all: It fully collapse the sensor tree.
Main area: the information that is shown in this area depends on the selected View. There are four available views in order to visualize our network infrastructure:

Tree: list with the different levels that compose the network infrastructure classified by dependency and hierarchy. Alongside each element are two icons for editing and deleting actions. This is the view that is displayed by default.
Map: locate the domains and sensors over a map.
Access Points: direct access to the visualization of the deployed Access Points.

Sensors: in the View the user can find a list of available sensors depending on the Apps included in your license. Click on the sensor you want to check for view an alphabetic list of all the sensors associated with this App.

note.title: Note
note.para: Each view has its own options menu and the different possibilities of creation and edition of the sensors or domains.
Map view hasn't any available option.

section.title: Options
section.para: Here are the options available in the Sensors section. They can be selected from the Options and from the options shown by clicking "Edit" both domain level and sensor level.

listitem.para: Import Tree
This option allows to import your network infrastructure through the uploading of a file to redBorder platform. This will be shown in tree view.
There are two ways to import tree:
Edit icon (domain level)
Export Tree
This option allows to export a tree and is within easy reach for other applications. User will download a zip file for storing then in their computer.
There are two ways to export a tree:
Edit icon (domain level)
Wakeup Chef Cluster
Cluster data
Indexed data: Show indexed data statistics for the cluster
Historicals: Show information about the historical data of the cluster
Realtime: Shows information about Realtime process

section.title: View
section.para: When the user access to the Sensors section can find a list (Tree view) in which the domains and sensors that are a part of their network infrastructure are shown. In this point we are going to review each view and the actions available.

section.title: Tree view
section.para: Tree view is shown by default in the Sensors section. It is a list with the different levels that compose the network infrastructure classified by dependency and hierarchy.

From this view, the user can add a new domain or sensor, delete the existing, access to other views, import and export the tree as well as direct editing of all the domains and sensors that are a part of the list.
Every element that is shown in the tree has two icons: Edit and Delete. (The same icons work in tree and sensors view):

note.title: Note
note.para: The options in the Edit menu can change depending on if we are consulting the infrastructure at domain or at sensor level.

warning.title: Warning
warning.para: In these cases, the "Delete" icon will appear colored in grey. Before the domain or sensor will be deleted, the system will show you a pop-up screen with a warning message.

All the users and descendants assigned to this domain or sensor will be disable and assigned to the parents of this domain or root domain. The user with Administrator role should activate user's permissions from Tools>Users section.

caption.para: Confirm the deleting of the sensor

section.para: In case that IPS/IDS sensors have been registered an icon with the type of policy it has will be shown.
Click on this icon to access the interface for this policy and from which we can perform some different actions.

listitem.para: Add a new domain or sensor
Delete a domain or sensor
Access to other views
Import and Export the tree
Edit a domain or sensor

section.title: Infrastructure organization levels in redBorder

listitem.para: Domain: containers which may include sensors, group of sensors, etc. Domain level shows us the domain name and allows us to add a description. It is possible to classify them according to their nature (organizational, spacial, etc.); each one will have an identifying icon:.
Sensors: end nodes that correspond with physical elements placed on the network (switches, routers, IPS, etc.).
The information in sensor level is: sensor name, IP, policy (IPS sensors), last check and version. It is possible to add a description to the sensor.

note.title: Note
note.para: Note that to create IPS sensors you must do that through the registration of the sensors in the Manager in the Manager Installation process. From this section you can edit and overwrite the parameters that they have inherited from Tools->General Settings
The sensors of the rest of the Apps can be created from Sensors section.

section.para: In Tools section we find General Settings option from which the user can define general parameters of the Manager and Apps.
This is the maximum level of configuration (it acts as root domain) therefore, the properties defined here will be inherited by domains and sensors that fall below this level.

When a domain or sensor is created or it is edited for the first time, we can observe that some parameters have the tag "Inherited", it means that they have inherited the values from General Settings. Overwrite this information in case that you want to change it.
The domains and sensors that fall below the level of the element overwritten, inherit again, the properties applied to this element.

section.title: Monitors

note.title: Note
note.para: This option is only available in the Edit icon menu (sensor level).

section.para: Click on sensor's Edit icon and select Monitor option. Then, we can see a list with the monitoring metrics using for monitor the sensor status at different levels. Technology column indicates the origin from where the data is collected.
These are the available actions for controlling the satus of the sensor:

listitem.para: Restore default: applies default metrics that are included in sensors creation.
Add monitor: shows available metrics. (+Add Monitor)
Delete monitor: delete the metric applied.

section.title: Map view
section.para: In this view, the user can see where the domains and sensors are located. It is possible to add a new location, both for a new domain/sensor and for an existing one.
To add a sensor to Map view itâs necessary to add first a location in the domain or sensor editing interface that has been selected.

For this, you can edit them when you add a new one (+Add Sensor/Domain) or by editing an existing one using the Edit icon. In both cases you will find a paragraph called Location in which a Map is shown; you can find the desired location or point by clicking on the map. Then select +Add Location tab.
If you have searched or selected a localization, the fields with the coordinates will be shown filled. Otherwise, insert manually that values.

caption.para: Define coordinates to add a location for a sensor or domain

section.title: View Access Points
section.para: Access Points (AP) are access points of the network infrastructure which are associated with a location. The Access Points depend on the Flow App and apply to both the domain level, as well as the sensors.

This is another way to display your network infrastructure, through the distribution of the APs per domain, and you can also view the status of each AP. You can access the display or create access points in two different ways:

listitem.para: View->Access Points
Edit icon to sensor/domain level->Edit: View Access Points (located in the submenu upper right side).

note.title: Note
note.para: To find out which level you are, you can check the shipping route in the upper left margin. You can browse through the different screens by clicking on any of the items of the route.

section.para: The submenu of this interface shows a series of buttons similar to those on the main screen Sensors. The actions you can perform from this screen are as follows (these vary depending on whether it is consulting a domain or sensor level):

listitem.para: Show Map/ Show Floors: shows the geographical distribution of access points or its plant location in the case we are consulting a domain Floor with more than a floor level.
Edit (sensor name or domain): we return to the editing screen for the domain or sensor.
Options->Export Access Points/ Delete All Access Points.: allows you to export all Access Points to a .csv file or delete all the Access Points defined for that localization.
+Add sensors: add sensors to the domain we are consulting.
View: menu that allows us to navigate through the different existing views.

caption.para: Add a new Access Point zone

section.title: Add a new domain
section.para: Select option +Add Domain which is located in the upper right submenu, choose the type of domain you want to add, and then fill out the required fields (these vary depending on the type of domain to be created).

caption.para: Add a domain: fill in the data to create

section.para: From this moment, the rest of the information associated with the domain will need to be modified by clicking the edit button to the right of each domain in the tree view, or Access Points and selecting the option Edit.

section.title: Edit a domain
section.para: From this interface you can modify the settings of an existing domain, and enter the information of a newly created domain.
To access this screen the user must click the edit button to the right of the domain you want to edit from the tree view or Access Points and select the optionEdit.
This is the general data that we can modify for the domains. However, depending on the type of domain selected, one of these fields will appear:

listitem.para: General: Displays general information of the sensor. Name (not editable from the Web), type of domain-select the domain type in the box) and description.
Servers: In this section the user can define the configuration of the Proxy and Syslog servers. All values shown are inherited by default. Overwrite if necessary.
Location: Locate the sensor/domain on a world map. This location will be displayed in the view Map.

section.title: Add a sensor
section.para: Among the submenu options, we find +Add Sensor. In the dropdown menu they show the different sensors available to add to the network infrastructure.
Select the type of sensor in the drop-down menu, and then complete the information requested.
It is also possible to claim a sensor from a remote proxy by using the option in the drop-down menu and entering the UUID of the sensor.

important.title: Important
important.para: In the moment in which a redBorder sensor is created, by default it's set as the root, above the domain level.
The user can organize its sensor infrastructure in any moment, dragging and dropping the sensor in the level they want to place it in.
The sensor automatically inherits the properties of the root domain (policies, operating mode, Snort variables, etc.).

section.title: Sensor types and devices configuration
section.para: In the sensor section of a redBorder manager, the user can find the different types of sensors, each one performs a different function:

listitem.para: Flow: For monitoring and supervision of the data traffic received.
MSE: To provide services related to mobility
Meraki: Specific sensor desinged to integrate the Cisco Meraki solution.
Aruba ALE: To collect data from Wi-Fi networks enabled mobile devices (protecting personal privacy).
Monitor device: To maintain full control over the state of the infrastructure.
Twitter: Designed to collect activity from Twitter use.
Vault: Allows to visualize and analyze the logs received from the different services and devices.
Mail Gateway: Sensor through which mail traffic passes (SMTP).
Claim Sensor: Allows to link the manager with the client proxy, which is centralized software that collects data from a client's request and sends it to the manager.

section.title: Monitor device
section.para: The monitor device sensor is one of the latest developments that comes with the 80-6 version of redBorder. It can be used to monitor any device with an ip address that supports snmp, redfish or ipmi. When creating or updating the monitor device sensor the credentials for the corresponding protocols needs to be defined. In case no community string for snmp is defined, the default âpublicâ will be used.
Once the user are logged in into the Manager dashboard, the sensor can be added using the menu âSensors > Add sensorâ and then clicking on âMonitor deviceâ.
It can be prompted for some required and optional parameters.

listitem.para: A unique name
The ip address of the machine the user want to monitor
The protocol the user will use to monitor
The credentials of the machine to access the selected protocol
The community string in case the user will use snmp protocol

caption.para: Press on the âSaveâ button to apply the configuration

note.title: Note
note.para: Different sensor configuration guides can be found on the reBorder support page:

section.title: Mail Gateway
section.para: Sensor through which mail traffic (SMTP) passes. It works as a simple MTA (Mail Traffic Agent). When the sensor receives an email, it forwards it to the corresponding mail server. In addition, it also sends to the Manager a copy of the emails and their attachments including additional data. this sensor must be registered in the Manager for its correct operation.

section.title: Installation and registration of Mail Gateway sensors
section.para: The installation process for the Mail Gateway sensor basically consists of three steps: configuration network, registering the sensor in the Manager and configuring the general parameters of the sensor in the redborder platform. To do this, you must have the installation wizard (ISO image) obtained via download or through the DVD provided by redborder.
When starting the installation wizard, we will see the main menu in which you will find the option Install Gateway Sensor:

textobject.phrase: Redborder Setup Wizard: Install Mail Gateway Sensor

caption.para: Redborder Setup Wizard: Install Mail Gateway Sensor

section.para:
Next, the user must enter their username and password
The username and password to be entered in this step correspond to those indicated in the Manager installation process and will be used to access the redborder web platform.
, and run the command rb_sysconf:

listitem.para: Login
Password
rb_sysconf

section.title: Network configuration of the Gateway sensors
section.para: Once rb_sysconf has been executed go to redBorder configuration menu.
This menu has 4 options:

listitem.para: System Configuration: From this option you can define and modify a series of basic system settings such as name, time, keyboard type, etc.
Network Configuration: this is the option from which all are made network configurations.
Passwords: use this option if you want to change the password.
quit: Exit.

note.title: Note
note.para: Remember: press Enter for default values.

section.para: As mentioned at the beginning of the chapter, the first step to start configuring the sensors Mail Gateway is to set network parameters.
To start the process select the option 2) Network Configuration from redBorder configuration menu.
These are the steps to follow to install Mail Gateway sensors:

listitem.para: Management Network configuration:
Add bond and set management interface.
DNS and domain configuration

note.title: Note
note.para: The order to be followed in the steps that comprise the configuration of the management network is indifferent. The order indicated in this installation manual is the one considered most optimal.
Until this configuration has been carried out, it will not be possible to proceed with the registration of the sensors in the Manager.

warning.title: Warning
warning.para: For the installation and registration of the Mail Gateway sensors it is necessary to have only one bond.
In case the system is installed on a real computer that has more than one network card, the user must choose which will be the management bond.

section.title: Creating a new bond and assigning ports
section.para: Once we have accessed the redborder Network configuration menu, select the option 1) Management Network Configuration from which we can create a bond for the installation of the sensor.
To illustrate this process we will create a bonding (bond0) and assign 2 ports to it.
Select the option n that appears in the submenu on the right side of the screen.
Once you have reviewed the ports that are available, select the one you want assign to bonding, as it appears in the lower margin of the previous screen.
The number that appears between square brackets [] is the one that defines the system by flaw. To select this number, press Enter.
The selected port will disappear from the available ports option.

important.title: Important
important.para: The system only allows the creation of a maximum of 4 bonds: (0-3).

section.title: Finish the bonding creation process
section.para: Before applying changes and finishing the bonding creation process, the system will show you a table that shows the new bonding created (bond0) together with the ports that have been assigned, the IP and Mask and the route assigned.
In order to save changes, select option a.
You can delete the created bond(s) at any time by selecting the option delete bonding pressing d.
To return to the main network configuration menu, select the option quit pressing q.

section.title: DNS and domain configuration
section.para: Start the setup by selecting: 2) DNS and domain settings.
PTo perform the configuration correctly, the user must enter:

listitem.para: Domain name
DNS primary
DNS secondary (optional)

section.para: Once this information has been entered, the system will warn that this configuration has been applied correctly.
To finish the process, it is necessary to apply changes: select the option apply pressing a.

section.title: Sensors registration in the Manager
section.para: To finish the installation process of the Mail Gateway sensors, the last step that must be carried out out is the RSensors registration in the Manager.
Until registration is complete, a message will be displayed indicating that the Sensors have not yet been registered in the Manager.

caption.para: Starting sensor registration in the Manager

section.para: In the sensor registration menu in the Manager we find the following options:

listitem.para: Hostname [rbsensor]: give a name to the sensor.
Set local time: Set local time.
IP address for rB Master Manager [127.0.0.1]: enter the IP of the Manager.

Register rB Sensor/Manager: registration of sensors in the manager Sensor/Manager. Until the registration process has been completed, the user will see the next message labeled in red: (not registered yet)

section.title: Give a name to the sensor (Hostname)
section.para: Select option Hostname [rbsensor] from the menu pressing 1.

Then, in Insert Hostname [rbsensor]: Write the name that you want to give the sensor to be registered in the Manager. As of right now, this is the name that will be displayed on the web when you access the list of IPS sensors.

caption.para: Give a name to the sensor

note.title: Note
note.para: Remember to enter a consistent name for the sensor. Avoid using the name âSensorâ, as that this is the generic name used by the Manager and that, in the long run, it could cause confusion.

warning.title: Warning
warning.para: The system will ask you to verify that the chosen name is correct, in that case, press Enter
If you wish to modify it, press n
The system will change the name of the sensor. To continue with the process and return to the menu redborder system configuration, press any key as indicated Press a key to continue...

section.title: Set local time
section.para: Select option 2) Set local time.
Insert date and time of the time zone corresponding to the country in which you are. This should match the one selected in the basic settings phase during the IPS sensor setup process.
The system shows two possible formats for inserting the date and time:

listitem.para: [HH:mm] or [YYYY/MM/DD]

section.para: Press Enter to continue with the registration process.

caption.para: Sensor registration in the Manager: Setting local time

section.title: IP address for rB Master Manager
section.para: Select option 3) IP address for rB Master Manager [00.0.000.00].
Insert the IP address or domain name of the computer used by the user. The system will verify whether it is reachable. This process may take a few seconds.
The system will synchronize the time of the computers and then restart a couple of services in order to finish the time synchronization.
!Congratulations! Your device is ready to register the sensors in the Manager.
To continue with the process and return to the menu redborder system configuration, press any key as indicated Press a key to continue...

section.title: Sensor registration in the Manager
section.para: This is the last step that completes the process of installing and configuring the Mail Gateway sensor with the redborder installation wizard.
From this moment on, you will be able to work directly from the redborder platform where you will have to make the last general configurations for the Mail Gateway sensor, as will be seen later.

para.emphasis: Finish the sensor registration process in the Manager

section.para: The steps to follow to complete the sensor registration process in the Manager are as follows:

listitem.para: Indicate whether you like to have a debug output: Would you like to have a debug output? Select the default option (No) by pressing N.
Insert password: indicate the password that has been given in the basic settings during Manager configuration.
Time synchronization (automatic) between the Manager and the sensors. This process may take a few seconds to complete.

section.para: After completing these steps, the system will notify you with a message that the sensor has been successfully registered.

para.literal: Sensor registered succesfully with chef server

warning.title: Warning
warning.para: Do not change the name of the sensor or hostname Do not change the name of the sensor once it has been registered. If you want to make changes, you will need to undo the entire registration process and start over.

section.para: To continue with the process and return to the menu redborder system configuration, press any key as indicated Press a key to continue...
In the sensor registration menu in the redborder Manager you can check that the sensor has been successfully registered:(Registered).
To exit the sensor registration wizard, select the option quit pressing q.

section.title: Editing and configuring Mail Gateway sensors
section.para: To configure Mail Gateway sensors, it is necessary to access the redborder web platform by inserting the management IP assigned to the Manager in the address bar of your browser.

note.title: Note
note.para: It is possible to log in to the platform using the account defined by default: admin using the password that you entered during the Manager installation process.

warning.title: Warning
warning.para: The management web will not work if you try to access it through an unencrypted web.

section.para: Configuration of the Mail Gateway sensors can be done in two ways:

listitem.para: General configuration of all Mail Gateway sensors: Tools -> Malware Settings -> Mail Gateway.
Particular configuration of each of the Mail Gateway sensors: Sensors -> "Edit" icon for each of the sensors.

caption.para: General Configuration of Mail Gateway Sensors

section.para: Next, each one of the configuration screens is explained, as well as the parameters that can be modified for the detection of Malware in your network.

section.title: General Settings: General Configuration of Mail Gateway Sensors
section.para: From the interface Tools -> Malware Settings the user can make the general configuration to apply to all registered sensors. Remember that this level acts as a root, so that those sensors that are below it will inherit the configuration that has been defined in this interface.

note.title: Note
note.para: It is possible to override the general settings of the Mail Gateway sensors at the individual level by editing them in the section Sensors selecting the sensor to be edited in the tree or in the list that appears in Sensors -> View -> Gateway Sensors.

section.para: These are the sections that the user must edit for the root level configuration of the Mail Gateway sensors:

listitem.para: General
Mail Gateway
Blacklist
Whitelist

section.title: Sensors: individual configuration of Mail Gateway sensors
section.para: To edit the configuration of any of the Mail Gateway sensors individually, the user must go to the section Sensors located on the right side of the header menu. You will then need to select the sensor you wish to edit.
In the tree view, the Mail Gateway sensors are accompanied by an identification icon. You can also search for the sensor in the list that is displayed from View -> Gateway Sensors.

caption.para: Sensors: ways to edit a sensor
List of Mail Gateway sensors: Sensors -> View -> Gateway Sensors

section.para: Within the menu that is displayed we find the following options:

listitem.para: Edit: allows editing a sensor's configuration at an individual level.
Quarantine: list of emails that are in quarantine.
Filter Policies: configuration and assignment of Filter Policies for each sensor.

section.para: To start editing the sensor parameters select Edit.
In the sensor editing interface, the following information will be entered. To save the sensor configuration, click the button Update.

note.title: Note
note.para: The name, IP and version fields are not editable, since this information is entered in the sensor configuration and registration process.

section.title: Gateway Settings
section.para: In this section, the user can define the behavior of the sensor based on the values entered in each of the fields shown in it.

listitem.para: Relay Host: Specify the IP of the final mail server.
Message Size Limit: Define the maximum size of messages that can be received.
Max Paralell Process: Indicate the maximum number of parallel processes handled by the Mail Gateway.
API timeout (seconds): Define the maximum waiting time for obtaining a valid score from the remote cache.
Email detained timeout (seconds): This field indicates the maximum waiting time for obtaining a valid score from the remote cache. After this time the file will be passed.

Quarantine timeout (days): Configure the days that have to pass since a file identified as Malware is blocked and retained until an action is defined to manage it. If no action is performed or the indicated time is exceeded, the file is discarded.
Cache Sync (hours) (minutes): Indicate the maximum time that must pass for the synchronization of the local and remote cache. Value in hours and minutes.
Maximum number of stored log files: Delimit the maximum time that the file will remain stored in the email history.

section.title: Relay Domains
section.para: In this section the user must define which domain or domains are going to be managed by the sensor.
Here is a list of the domains that have already been added. The user can eliminate at any time those domains that are not in use or that they consider should not be managed by the sensor.
To add a new domain just click on the tab +Add Domains and enter the domain you want to associate, click on Update to save.

warning.title: Warning
warning.para: Once you have finished editing the Mail Gateway sensor, click on Update to apply the changes made.

section.title: Quarantine
section.para: There are two ways to get to the list of quarantined emails:

listitem.para: Total quarantined emails for all registered Mail Gateway sensors: Sensors -> Options -> Mail Quarantine
Quarantined emails for a specific sensor: Sensors -> "Edit" icon for each of the sensors -> Quarantine

section.para: In both cases, the interface shows a list of all the emails that have been quarantined and the following information:

listitem.para: Timestamp: reception date and time.
Sensor through which the mail has passed.
Email sender: sender's email.
Email Destinations: recipient's email.
URLs: number of URLs included in the mail.
Files: number of files included in the mail.
Email ID: email id number.

section.para: Free email: At any time, the user can release from the quarantine those emails that they consider have already been analyzed and do not represent a danger. To do this, click on the following icon:
Remove email: click the "Delete" icon.

section.title: Filter Policies: Mail Gateway sensors
section.para: To access the creation or edition of the Filter Policies the user has two different ways:

listitem.para: Total Filter Policies created for the root sensor: Sensors -> Options -> Filter Policies
Filter Policies for a specific sensor: Sensors -> "Edit" icon for each of the sensors -> Filter Policies

caption.para: List of Filter Policies for the root sensor

section.para: In both cases, the user accesses an interface which shows a list with all the Filter Policies that have been created for that sensor. The policy that is active (assigned) will be shaded green.
To assign a policy to a sensor, click on the button Assign. To apply the policy assigned to the sensor select the option Apply.
To unassign a policy select the option Clear.

caption.para: List of Filter Policies for a Mail Gateway sensor

section.title: Creating a new Filter Policy
section.para: Once you have accessed the Filter Policies interface to create a new policy, simply select the option +New Policy. The user must indicate at least one name for the new policy and optionally insert a description.
Below you must indicate the rules that are included in this policy. The procedure will vary depending on whether you want to apply the policy at the Hash, URL or IP level.
To define the rules of the policy, simply click on the policy to be modified or by clicking on the "Edit" icon.
The Filter Policies editing interface consists of two sections: Edit Filter Policy and Threshold Configuration. In both sections the user can edit the following information:

listitem.para: CachÃ© query method: the user must indicate the type of queries they want to be made to the cache.
Apply Filter Policy for: Select the type of object to analyze.
Score to consider element as Malware: indicate the score from which an object is considered Malware.
Drop files that exceed this size (MB) (this field is only enabled if you have selected to apply the Hash policy): indicate the maximum size of the files from which they will be blocked by the system.

note.title: Recommended configuration
note.para: Cache query method: Local+API
Apply Filter Policy for: it is recommended to select all three types of objects (Hash, URL and IP).

section.para: In the event that the box corresponding to Hash has been activated (Apply Filter Policy for:), a new section will be displayed in the lower margin: File Rules.
This section shows a list of the type of files on which actions can be performed. The available actions are:

listitem.para: Filter
Drop (block)
Pass

section.para: To apply the new configuration select the option Save.

section.title: Malware events (Mail Gateway)
section.para: To carry out a deep monitoring and analysis of the objects that are interacting with our network, the user can make a series of actions from the Malware section located on the left margin of the header menu.

note.title: Viewing the objects detected by the Mail Gateway sensor
note.para: To view the events produced by the objects detected by the Mail Gateway sensor, the user can select the attributes corresponding to Hash, URL and IP using the option +Add Tab.
In this way, those attributes will be added to the view and the user will be able to perform different actions on them.

section.para: Once we have added the desired attributes to the view, we can view a summary with the events produced by them. Clicking on any of these elements displays a submenu from which you can perform object analysis and monitoring actions.

caption.para: Attributes submenu in Malware event view

section.title: Outliers
section.para: By activating this option, the anomalies of the events of the selected attribute will be marked in the view. This action is very useful to isolate anomalous behavior within the traffic flow.

section.title: Filenames (Hash)
section.para: Thanks to this option the user obtains from a Hash the successive names that a file has had. This simplifies the identification of a file that has been assigned a single hash even though it has had different names.

section.title: Analysis
section.para: When selecting the option Analysis the user visualizes a complete summary about the status of the file.
The following information is displayed in the Analysis view:

listitem.para: This section shows the progress of the file analysis and the information corresponding to the external reputation services.
It is possible to download the file that is being analyzed using the option Download File. A compressed file will be downloaded in .zip format, whose password is infected.
This section shows in greater detail the process and result of the analysis carried out by the different chargers or reputation services.
It is possible to download the history of the file in JSON format.

note.title: Note
note.para: These are the values that may appear as a result of the analysis carried out by the loaders:
-: unanalyzed item.
Unknown: the element has been analyzed, but the result is unknown (equivalent to a score of -1).

note.title: Note
note.para: At any time you can switch to the Evolution or Propagation view of the object being analyzed, thanks to the possibility of jumping from one view to another using the options displayed in the upper right margin: Show Evolution/Show Propagation.

section.title: Evolution
section.para: Evolution shows the time evolution of the different events collected by each of the sensors that are registered in the Manager.

At the top of the screen there is a graphical representation of this evolution on a timeline. Depending on the volume of the circles, a greater or lesser number of events will have been recorded for a given period of time.
It is possible to visualize the evolution of an object in a specific time by selecting Filter Time.

At the bottom, a detailed summary of each of the events per sensor is offered, specifying the score assigned to the object being analyzed, the sensor, SRC Address, DST Address, the sending email, the receiving emails and the number of events. generated by that object (in the image they are registered events for that Hash/file).

note.title: Note
note.para: At any time you can switch to the Analysis or propagation view of the object whose evolution is being analyzed, thanks to the possibility of jumping from one view to another using the options displayed in the upper right margin: Show Analysis/Show Propagation.

section.title: Propagation
section.para: When selecting the option Propagation we access an interface that graphically shows us the propagation of that object (in the hash image or file) through the IPs or Emails of our organization.
By clicking on any of the nodes displayed (source and destination IPs/emails), a summary of all the events associated with that node in the selected period of time is displayed at the bottom.
Likewise, placing the mouse over any of the nodes will highlight the nodes (IPs/Emails) that have interacted with it.

important.title: Important
important.para: It is possible to filter a specific element by entering its data in the search engine located on the right margin. When starting to write the data, those matching nodes will be highlighted.
